009package Ch14_Colorimetric_Color;
010
011import ij.ImagePlus;
012import ij.gui.NewImage;
013import ij.plugin.filter.PlugInFilter;
014import ij.process.ColorProcessor;
015import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
016import imagingbook.common.color.RgbUtils;
017import imagingbook.common.color.cie.CieUtils;
018import imagingbook.common.color.cie.CieXyPlot;
019import imagingbook.common.color.colorspace.sRgbColorSpace;
020import imagingbook.common.ij.DialogUtils;
021import imagingbook.common.ij.overlay.ColoredStroke;
022import imagingbook.common.ij.overlay.ShapeOverlayAdapter;
023import imagingbook.sampleimages.GeneralSampleImage;
024
025import java.awt.Color;
026import java.awt.Shape;
027import java.awt.color.ColorSpace;
028
029import static imagingbook.common.ij.IjUtils.noCurrentImage;
030
031/**
032 * ImageJ plugin, takes any RGB color image and plots its color distribution in CIE xy-space, together with the
033 * outline of the xy ("horseshoe") chromaticity outline.
034 */
035public class Plot_Chromaticity_Chart implements PlugInFilter {
036
037    private static int ImageSize = 512;
038
039    /**
040     * Constructor, asks to open a predefined sample image if no other image is currently open.
041     */
042    public Plot_Chromaticity_Chart() {
043        if (noCurrentImage()) {
044            DialogUtils.askForSampleImage(GeneralSampleImage.Flower);
045        }
046    }
047
048    @Override
049    public int setup(String arg, ImagePlus imp) {
050        return DOES_RGB + NO_CHANGES;
051    }
052
053    @Override
054    public void run(ImageProcessor ip) {
055        ColorProcessor cp = (ColorProcessor) ip;
056        ImagePlus imPlot =
057                NewImage.createRGBImage("Cie Chromaticity (xy)", ImageSize, ImageSize, 1, NewImage.FILL_WHITE);
058        ColorProcessor cpPlot = (ColorProcessor) imPlot.getProcessor();
059        cpPlot.setColor(Color.lightGray);
060        cpPlot.fill();
061
062        ColorSpace cs = sRgbColorSpace.getInstance();
063
064        int[] pixels = (int[]) cp.getPixels();
065
066        int[] RGB = new int[3];
067        for (int i = 0; i < pixels.length; i++) {
068            int p = pixels[i];
069            // from RGB, calculate XYZ and xy:
070            RgbUtils.decodeIntToRgb(p, RGB);
071            float[] srgb = RgbUtils.normalize(RGB);
072            float[] XYZ = cs.toCIEXYZ(srgb);
073            float[] xy = CieUtils.XYZToxy(XYZ);
074            int xx = (int) Math.round(xy[0] * ImageSize);
075            int yy = (int) Math.round((1 - xy[1]) * ImageSize);
076
077            // place a brighness-normalized image pixel at the (xy) position:
078            float[] XYZn = CieUtils.xyToXYZ(xy[0], xy[1]);
079            float[] srgbn = cs.fromCIEXYZ(XYZn);
080            int[] RGBn = RgbUtils.denormalize(srgbn);
081            cpPlot.putPixel(xx, yy, RGBn);
082        }
083
084        ShapeOverlayAdapter ola = new ShapeOverlayAdapter();
085        Shape xyPlot = new CieXyPlot(ImageSize);
086        ola.addShape(xyPlot, new ColoredStroke(0.35, Color.blue));
087
088        imPlot.setOverlay(ola.getOverlay());
089        imPlot.show();
090    }
091}
